questions.text: Action of the muscle, marked by arrow, at metacarpophalangeal joins is ?
questions.solution:
The marked muscle is 1st Lumbrical.

  • Lumbricals arise from 4 tendons of flexor digitorum profundus muscle and inserted into dorsum of bases of distal phalanges via extensor expansion.
  • 1st and 2nd Lumbricals are unipennate and 3rd and 4th Lumbricals are bipennate.
  • Action : Flexion of Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and Extension of Interphalangeal joints.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. 9th Edition. Vol 1 . Chapter 9. p 135.

questions.text: Right coronary artery is the branch of?
questions.solution:
Heart is supplied by 2 coronary arteries, arising from the ascending aorta.

  • At the root of the aorta, there are 3 dilatations of the vessel wall, called the aortic sinuses.
  • The sinuses are anterior, Left posterior and right posterior.
  • The Right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus.
  • The Left coronary artery arises from the Left posterior aortic sinus.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. 9th Edition. Vol 1 . Chapter 18. p 305.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is derived from 1st pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Pharyngeal arches are five in number and present in the lateral wall and floor of the primitive pharynx.

  • The mesoderm of each arch gives rise to muscles. All these muscles are supplied by the nerve of the arch from which they develop.
  • Derivatives of Pharyngeal arches :

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology. Vishram Singh. 3rd Edition. Chapter 14. p 154.

questions.text: Identify the yellow arrow marked structure in the sagittal section of brain in given MRI?
questions.solution:
The yellow arrow marked structure is Fornix .

  • The fornix is a large bundle of mainly projection fibres which connects the hippocampus with the mammillary body.
  • It constitutes sole efferent system of the hippocampus.
  • On medial surface of cerebral hemisphere, it is seen as an arched prominent bundle of white fibres below the corpus callosum, along the lower border of septum pellucidum.

Reference: Textbook of clinical Neuroanatomy. Vishram Singh. 4th Edition. Chapter 19. p235.

questions.text: Given in the following image are which type of fibres?
questions.solution:
The fornix is a large bundle of mainly Projection fibres which connects the hippocampus with the mammillary body.

  • There are 3 types of white fibres in cerebral hemisphere.
  1. Association Fibres : interconnects different regions cerebral cortex of same hemisphere.
  • - Short association fibres : interconnect adjacent gyri. also called arcuate fibres.
  • Long association fibres : interconnect widely separated gyri. exa : Uncinate fasciculus, Cingulum, superior and inferior longitudinal bundles, Fronto occipital bundle.
  1. Commissural Fibres : interconnects identical areas of two hemisphere.
  • Examples : Corpus callosum, Anterior, Posterior, Habenular, Hippocampal
  1. Projection Fibres : connect the cerebral cortex to subcortical centres and spinal cord.
  • Example: Internal capsule, corona radiata, Fibria and Fornix.

Reference: Textbook of clinical Neuroanatomy. Vishram Singh. 4th Edition. Chapter 14. p166.

questions.text: Post Breast carcinoma surgery winging of scapula is seen due to injury to?
questions.solution:
Winging of scapula : Inferior angle and medial border of scapula become unduly prominent when patient pushes his hands against wall.

  • It is due to injury to long thoracic nerve.
  • Causes : stab injury, during removal of breast tumors
  • Long thoracic nerve is arise from C5,C6,C7 roots of brachial plexus, passes behind clavicle and superficial to 1st and 2nd ribs. It continues to descend longitudinally along side of thoracic wall, in mid axillary line on superficial surface of serratus anterior.

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy. Vishram Singh. 4th Edition. Volume I. Chapter 3. p38.

questions.text: A male presented with difficulty in foot eversion and sensory loss on the lateral leg and dorsum of foot. The nerve damaged is?
questions.solution:
Superficial peroneal nerve is one of the terminal branch of common peroneal nerve at the neck of fibula.

  • It gives muscular branches to peroneus longus and peroneus brevis. ( Evertor of foot).
  • It supply skin of lower one third of lateral side of leg and dorsum of the foot.
  • Deep Peroneal nerve is terminal branch of common peroneal nerve.
  • It supplies muscles of front of leg ( dorsiflexion of foot) and dorsum of foot.
  • It supplies skin of first interdigital cleft.
  • Injury to nerve lead to Foot Drop (loss of dorsiflexion of foot)

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy. Vishram Singh. 4th Edition. Volume II. Chapter : 29. p 393.

choices.text: Separates right and left hepatic lobes
Separates right anterior and right posterior sectors
Separates left medial and left lateral sectors

questions.text: The Cholecystocaval line separates which among the following?
questions.solution:
• On the basis of the intrahepatic distribution of the hepatic artery, the portal vein and biliary ducts, the liver can be divided into right and left functional hepatic lobes.
  • These physiological lobes are separated by a plane passing on anterosuperior surface along line joining the cystic notch to groove for the inferior vena cava.( cholecystocaval line).

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 23. p 358.

questions.text: Trendelenburg's sign is positive with paralysis of:
questions.solution:
• When the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei of the supported side raise the opposite and unsupported side of the pelvis. However , if the abductor mechanism is defective, the unsupported side of the pelvis drops and this is known as a positive Trendelenburg's sign.
  • The sign is positive in defects of power i.e. paralysis of glutei medius and minimus; defect of fulcrum, i.e congenital or pathological dislocation of the hip and defect of the weight, i.e. ununited fracture of the neck of the femur.
  • The superior gluteal nerve is a branch of the lumbosacral plexus. It supplies 3 muscles, the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus and the tensor fascia latae.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 5. p 81.

questions.text: Which of the following passes through foramen spinosum?
questions.solution:
• Foramen spinosum is a small circular foramen at the base of spine of sphenoid.
  • The foramen spinosum transmits the middle meningeal artery, meningeal branch of mandibular nerve ( Nervus spinosum) and the posterior trunk of the middle meningeal vein.
  • Mandibular nerve, accessory meningeal artery, lesser petrosal nerve pass through the foramen ovale.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 3. 9th edition. Chapter 1. p 19.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve nucleus is located deep to facial colliculus?
questions.solution:
• The floor of 4th ventricle is divided into right and left symmetrical halves by a median sulcus.
  • on either side of medial sulcus there is a longitudinal elevation called median eminence.
  • On either side , the median eminence shows an oval swelling in the pontine part of floor at the level of superior fovea, the facial colliculus. The swelling is produced by the fibres from the motor nucleus of facial nerve hooking around the abducent nucleus.

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy. Vishram Singh. 4th edition. Chapter 8. p 85.

questions.text: All the following abdominal structures are in posterior relation of kidney except?
questions.solution:
The posterior relations of kidneys are as follow:

  1. Diaphragm
  2. Medial and lateral arcuate ligaments
  3. Psoas major
  4. Quadratus lumborum
  5. Transversus abdominis
  6. Subcostal vessels
  7. Subcostal, iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves.
  8. 12th rib on right side, 11th and 12th rib on left side.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 24. p 365.

questions.text: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve has longer course due to the persistence of which pharyngeal artery?
questions.solution:
• The nerve of each branchial arch lies lateral to the corresponding dorsal aorta, and after passing through the mesodermal core of the arch the nerve crosses medially in front of the respective aortic arch artery. Nerve of sixth arch ( Recurrent laryngeal nerve) , however presents a different relation; it lies at first lateral to dorsal aorta and then hooks upwards crossing the caudal surface of 6th aortic arch.
  • The degeneration of the dorsal part of right sixth aortic arch and associated elongation of neck allow the right recurrent nerve to hook around caudal surface of right fourth aortic arch, which forms the proximal part of right subclavian artery.
  • Dorsal part of the left sixth aortic arch persists as the ductus arteriosus, and the left fourth arch forms a part of the arch of aorta. This explains why the left recurrent nerve retains its primitive relationship by winding round the caudal surface of arch of aorta dorsal to the ligamentum arteriosum.

Reference: Essential of Human Embryology. A K Datta. 6th edition. Chapter 15. p 178.

questions.text: Which branch of subclavian artery contributes to scapular anastomosis?
questions.solution:
• The scapular anastomoses occurs in the three fossae - subscapular, supraspinnous and infraspinous.
  • This anastomosis is between branches of 1st pat of subclavian artery and branches of 3rd part of axillary artery.
  • It is formed by
  1. The suprascapular artery - branch of the thyrocervical trunk from subclavian artery.
  2. The deep branch of transverse cervical artery - branch from thyrocervical trunk
  3. The circumflex scapular artery - branch of the subscapular artery from the 3rd part of axillary artery.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition. Chapter 6. p 84.

questions.text: Inversion and Eversion occurs at which of the following joints?
questions.solution:
• Inversion is a movement in which the medial border of the foot is elevated, so that the sole faces medially.
  • Eversion is a movement in which the lateral border if the foot is elevated, so that the sole faces laterally.
  • These movements can be performed voluntarily only when foot is off the ground. When the foot is on the ground movements help to adjust the foot to uneven ground.
  • In Inversion & Eversion , the entire part of foot below the talus moves together. The movements takes place mainly at the subtalar joint and talocalcaneonavicular joint and partly at transverse tarsal joint. The calcaneum and navicular bone, move medially or laterally round the talus carrying the forefoot with them.
  • Inversion is accompanied by the plantar flexion of foot and adduction of forefoot. Eversion is accompanied by dorsiflexion of foot and abduction of forefoot.
  • Muscles for Inversion : tibialis anterior & tibialis posterior.
  • Muscles for Eversion : Peroneus longus & Peroneus brevis.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 12. p 181.

questions.text: Tingling and painful sensation in the lateral region of the thigh may occur in the older, Overweight individuals as a result of bulging abdomen, compressing a nerve beneath the inguinal ligament. Which of the following nerve is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
• Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve ( L2,L3) : It is a branch of the lumbar plexus. It emerges behind the lateral end of the inguinal ligament , divides into anterior and posterior branches, and supplies the skin on the anterolateral side of the thigh and on the anterior part of the gluteal region.
  • Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve (L1,L2) : It pierces the femoral sheath and overlying deep fascia 2 cm below the midinguinal point, and supplies most of the skin over the femoral triangle.
  • Ilioinguinal nerve (L1) : It emerges at the superficial inguinal ring and supplies the skin at the root of the penis and over mons pubis in the female, the anterior one third of the scrotum or labium majus and the superomedial part of the thigh.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 3. p 47.

questions.text: Structure passing through the central tendon of diaphragm is: -
questions.solution:
• The diaphragm is a dome shaped muscle forming the partition between the thoracic and abdominal cavities. Muscle fibres form  the periphery of the partition. They arise from circumference of the thoracic outlet and are inserted into a central tendon.
  • There are three large or main opening in the diaphragm.
  1. Vena caval opening : It lies in the central tendon at level of 8th thoracic vertebra. It transmits
  2. Inferior vena cava (IVC)
  3. Branches of the right phrenic nerve
  4. Lymphatics of Liver
  5. Aortic opening : It is osseoaponeurotic at the level of 12th thoracic vertebra. It transmits
  6. Aorta
  7. Thoracic duct
  8. Azygos vein
  9. Oesphageal opening : It lies in the muscular part at the level of 10th thoracic vertebra.
  10. Oesophagus
  11. Gastric or vagus nerves
  12. Oesophageal branches of left gastric artery

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 26. p 389.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most cranial structure in the root of left lung?
questions.solution:
Root of the lung is a short , broad pedicle which connects the medial surface of the lung to the mediastinum. It is formed by structure which either enter or come out of the lung at the hilum.

- Arrangement of structure from above downwards :

Right Side : Eparterial bronchus, pulmonary artery, hyparterial bronchus, inferior pulmonary vein.

Left Side : Pulmonary artery, bronchus, inferior pulmonary artery.

- Arrangement of structure in hilum from anterior to posterior :

  • Superior pulmonary vein, pulmonary artery, bronchus, bronchial artery.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition. Chapter 16. p 274.

questions.text: The artery that lies deep to the marked area in the given image is a branch of which of the following artery?
questions.solution:
- The marked structure is Pterion.

- It is the meeting point of parietal, temporal, frontal and sphenoid bone.

- The Pterion overlies the anterior division of middle meningeal artery.

- The maxillary artery is the larger terminal branch of the external carotid artery. It is divided into three parts by the lower head of lateral pterygoid muscle.

  1. First part (Mandibular part) : from beginning to lower border of lateral pterygoid.
  2. Second part (Pterygoid part) : from lower border to the upper border of lower head of lateral pterygoid.
  3. Third part ( Pterygopalatine part) : from upper border of lower head of lateral pterygoid to Pterygopalatine fossa.

-Branches of Maxillary artery :


Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 3. 9th Edition. Chapter 6. p 127.

choices.text: Deviation of tongue to right side
Deviation of tongue to left side
Deviation of soft palate to right side
Deviation of tongue to left side

questions.text: Which of the following results in the Palsy of right genioglossus?
questions.solution:
- Genioglossus muscle is fan shaped muscle of tongue. It arise from superior genial tubercle of mandible and inserted to whole of tongue (Fibres radiate from the tip to the base ) and hyoid bone.

It protrude the tongue when acting together with its counterpart of opposite side. It is supplied by hypoglossal nerve.

- The genioglossi are commonly used for clinical testing of the hypoglossal nerve. The muscle of both sides acting together protrude the tongue whereas single muscle deviate the tongue to the opposite side. Therefore when patient is asked to protrude his tongue, the tongue deviates to the paralyzed side ( i.e. the side of lesion of the hypoglossal nerve).

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. . Volume 3. 9th Edition. Chapter 17. p 300.

questions.text: What is the arrow marked structure in the following image?
questions.solution:
- The arrow marked structure is Lentiform nucleus.

- Basal nuclei : are large masses of grey matter situated in the basal part of white core of each cerebral hemisphere lateral to thalamus. It includes :

  1. Corpus striatum (Caudate nucleus + Lentiform nucleus)
  2. Claustrum
  3. Amygdaloid body

- Corpus striatum is situated lateral to the thalamus and completely divided into caudate nucleus and lentiform nucleus by a band of nerve fibres, the internal capsule.

- Caudate Nucleus : is a large comma shaped mass of grey matter, which surrounds the thalamus and is itself surrounded by the lateral ventricle.

- Lentiform Nucleus : is large lens shaped (biconvex) mass of grey matter beneath the insula forming the lateral boundary of internal capsule. In horizontal section of cerebrum, it appears wedge shaped with broad convex base directed laterally.

- Claustrum : is thin saucer shaped mass of grey matter situated between the Putamen and insula.


Reference:Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy. Vishram Singh. 4th edition. Chapter 13. p 160.

questions.text: A patient came with history of fall and on examination there was tenderness between the extensor pollicis longus and brevis. Which of the following is the likely lesion?
questions.solution:
- The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression on lateral side of the wrist. It is bounded posteriorly by the tendon of extensor pollicis longus and anteriorly by the tendon of extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus.

- The floor of snuff box is formed by the scaphoid and the trapezium.

- It is crossed by radial artery.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. . Volume 1. 9th Edition. Chapter 9. p 149.

choices.text: Radial nerve in the radial groove

questions.text: 'FINGER DROP WITH NO WRIST DROP' is caused by lesion to which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
- 'FINGER DROP WITH NO WRIST DROP' is caused by lesion to Posterior interosseous nerve.

- Posterior interosseous nerve : It is a chief nerve of back of forearm. It is a branch of radial nerve given off in cubital fossa, just below the level of lateral epicondyle of humerus.

- Muscular branches :

  1. Before piercing supinator : to extensor carpi radialis brevis and supinator
  2. While passing through supinator : another branch to supinator
  3. After emerging from supinator :
  4. 3 short branches: to extensor digitorum, extensor digit minimi, extensor carpi ulnaris
  5. 2 long branches: to abductor pollicis longus , extensor pollicis brevis (lateral branch) and extensor pollicis longus , extensor indicis (medial branch )

- Injury to posterior interosseous nerve leads to paralysis of all extensor muscles of wrist and fingers except extensor carpi radialis longus, brachioradialis and anconeus.

- No wrist drop in injury to posterior interosseous nerve as extensor carpi radialis longus is spared.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th Edition. Chapter 9. p 155.

questions.text: All of the following are the branches of external carotid artery (ECA) supplying the nasal septum except:
questions.solution:
- The nasal septum is a median osseocartilaginous partition between two nasal cavities. It is supplied by the following arteries .

  1. Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery ( a branch of ophthalmic artery)
  2. Septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery ( a branch of ophthalmic artery)
  3. Septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery ( a branch of maxillary artery)
  4. Septal branch of the greater palatine artery ( a branch of maxillary artery)
  5. Septal branch of the superior labial artery ( a branch of facial artery)

- External carotid artery is one of the terminal branches of common carotid artery and supplies the structure external to the head and in front of the neck.

- External carotid artery gives rise to 8 branches as follow :

  1. Superior thyroid artery
  2. Lingual artery
  3. facial artery
  4. Occipital artery
  5. Posterior auricular artery
  6. Ascending pharyngeal artery
  7. Maxillary artery
  8. Superficial temporal artery.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. . Volume 3. 9th Edition. Chapter 15. p 272.

questions.text: The marked landmark corresponds to which structure?
questions.solution:
- The marked structure in image is medial epicondyle of humerus .

- The medial epicondyle of the humerus is a prominent bony projection on the medial side of the elbow. It is best seen and felt in a mid-flexed elbow.

- The ulnar nerve is branch of medial cord of the brachial plexus. It lies in the axilla between axillary vein and axillary artery on a deeper plane. It pierces medial intermuscular septum at the middle of arm and lie on its back and descends on the back of medial epicondyle of humerus where it can be palpated.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. . Volume 1. 9th Edition. Chapter 8. p 103.

questions.text: Identify the vagus nerve in this given cross-sectional diagram of the neck:
questions.solution:
• Above image is transverse section of Head and Neck at the level of the 6th cervical vertebra.
  • The marking structures are as follow:
    • A : Common Carotid artery
    • B : Internal jugular vein
    • C : Vagus nerve
    • D : Cervical sympathetic chain

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy. Vishram Singh. Volume III. 4th edition. Chapter 4. p 72.

questions.text: At birth, an infant presented with a stomach that has herniated into the diaphragm. Where is the defect that resulted in the herniation?
questions.solution:
• The diaphragm is a dome shaped musculotendinous partition between thoracic and abdominal cavities. The diaphragm is a composite strucutre that develops from the following 4 embryological components:
  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH): It is a herniation of abdominal contents into the pleural cavity through a large gap/defect present in posterolateral part of diaphragm.
  • This defect (Foramen of Bochdalek) occurs due to defective development of Pleuroperitoneal membrane.
  • When the abdominal contents like intestines, stomach and/or spleen herniate in the thorax, they compress the developing lungs and cause hypoplasia.
  • The diaphragmatic hernia is more common on the left side probably because right pleuroperitoneal canal closes earlier then left one.

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology. Vishram Singh. 3rd Edition. Chapter 21. p 228.

questions.text: A patient recovering from a traumatic injury to the face now finds himself unable to chew his food. On physical examination, his jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exits the skull through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
• A patient have traumatic injury to face. He unable to chew his food and his jaw deviated to the right side. Above clinical finding suggestive of injury to Mandibular nerve.
  • Mandibular nerve is the largest mixed branch of trigeminal nerve. It begins in the middle cranial fossa and leaves the cranial cavity through foramen ovale.
  • Branches of Mandibular nerve:
    1. From main trunk
      1. Meningeal branch
      2. Nerve to medial pterygoid
    2. From the anterior trunk:
      1. A sensory branch: the buccal nerve
      2. Motor branches: Muscles of mastication (Masseteric, deep temporal, nerve to lateral pterygoid)
    3. From the posterior trunk:
      1. Auriculotemporal nerve
      2. Lingual nerve
      3. Inferior alveolar nerve
  • Structure passing through foramen ovale: (MALE)
    1. Mandibular nerve
    2. Accessory meningeal artery
    3. Lesser petrosal nerve
    4. Emissary vein

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 3. 9th edition, Chapter 6. p 135.

questions.text: The midgut loop normally herniates through the primitive umbilical ring into the extraembryonic coelom during 6th of development. Failure of the intestinal loops to return to the abdominal cavity by 11th week results in the formation of:
questions.solution:
• During the 3rd week of IUL, the rapid growth of midgut loop and enlargement of liver at the same time, the abdominal cavity temporarily becomes too small to accommodate all the loops of midgut. Consequently, during the 6th week of IUL, the loop of midgut (intestine) herniate through umbilical opening to enter into remains of the extraembryonic coelom. This herniation of intestinal loops through umbilical opening is called physiological umbilical hernia.
  • If the intestinal loop fails to return into abdominal cavity, it is called as Exomphalos or Omphalocele.
  • Omphalocele presents as a rounded mass protruding from the umbilicus. This mass contains coils of small intestine and is covered by a transparent amniotic membrane.
  • It occurs in 2.5/10000 births and could be associated with cardiac and neural tube defects.
  • Gastroschisis: There is a linear defect in anterior abdominal wall through which abdominal contents herniates out. This defect is produced when lateral folds of embryo fail to fuse with each other around connecting stalk.

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology. Vishram Singh. 3rd edition. Chapter 18. p 198.

questions.text: The following form the boundaries of Koch's triangle except:
questions.solution:
• Koch's triangle is bounded by
    1. Ostium of coronary sinus
    2. Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve
    3. Tendon of Todaro.
  • Left coronary artery arises from the left posterior aortic sinus of ascending aorta.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition, Chapter 18. p 297.

questions.text: Following an incised wound in the front of wrist, the subject is unable to oppose the tips of the little finger and the thumb. The nerve (s) involved is/are?
questions.solution:
• The ulnar nerve passing superficial and median nerve passing deep to the flexor retinaculum at wrist. Incised wound in front of wrist leads to injury to this nerves.
  • Opposition of little finger and the thumb is produced by Opponens pollicis and Opponens digiti minimi.
  • Opponens pollicis is supplied by median nerve and it pulls thumb medially and forward across palm (opposes thumb towards the fingers).
  • Opponens digiti minimi is supplied by deep branch of ulnar nerve and it pulls fifth metacarpal forward as in cupping the palm.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition, Chapter 9. p 135.

questions.text: Abduction of the shoulder joint above 900 is because of __________ ?
questions.solution:
• The Shoulder joint is a synovial joint of ball and socket variety.
  • In abduction, the arm moves anterolaterally away from the trunk.
  • The overhead abduction of shoulder joint are brought about by smooth and coordinate motion at all joints of shoulder complex: Glenohumeral (shoulder joint), sternoclavicular, acromioclavicular and scapulothoracic.
  • The shoulder joint contributes 100-120 degree of flexion and 90-120 degree of abduction to the total 180 degree of overhead abduction. This makes the overall ratio of 2 degree of motion of shoulder to 1 degree of scapulohumeral rhythm. Thus for every 15 degree of elevation, 10 degree occurs at shoulder joint and 5 degree are due to movement of shoulder joint.
  • Serratus anterior is chiefly inserted into inferior angle of scapula. It rotates this angle laterally. trapezius rotates medial border at root of spine of scapula downwards. The synergic action of these two muscle turns the glenoid cavity upwards increasing the range of abduction at the shoulder joint.
  • Supraspinatus and deltoid involved abduction throughout the range of from 0-90 degree.
  • Biceps (short head) brings flexion of shoulder joint.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition, Chapter 10. p 165.

questions.text: Following a deep cut overlying the hypothenar eminence, it is observed that the patient cannot hold a sheet of paper between the 2nd and 3rd digits. Which of the following nerve is most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
• The patient cannot hold a sheet of paper between 2nd and 3rd digit due to paralysis of palmar interossei muscle as palmar interossei are adductor of digits at metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • All four palmar interossei are supplied by deep branch of ulnar nerve.
  • Ulnar nerve: It is the main nerve of the hand and enters the palm by passing superficial to flexor retinaculum. It divided into superficial and deep branch.
  • Superficial branch: It supplies palmaris brevis muscle and supply skin of medial one and half digits.
  • Deep branch: It passes between abductor and flexor digiti minimi and than between opponens digiti minimi and fifth metacarpal bone, lying on hook of hemate. It gives muscular branches to
    1. Three hypothenar muscle
    2. Medial 2 lumbricals and 8 interossei (4 palmar interossei and 4 dorsal interossei)
    3. Adductor pollicis

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition, Chapter 09. p 140.

questions.text: Tingling and painful sensation in the lateral region of the thigh may occur in the older, overweight individuals as a result of bulging abdomen, compressing a nerve beneath the inguinal ligament. Which of the following nerve is likely involved?
questions.solution: Reference: kindly see the question and answer no. 16

questions.text: Which of the following is a syndesmosis?
questions.solution:
Inferior tibiofibular joint is a syndesmosis uniting the lower ends of the tibia and the fibula. The bony surfaces are connected by a very strong interosseous ligament.

The joints are structurally classified into three types:

  1. Fibrous joint: Here bones forming the joints are united by fibrous connective tissue.
    They are of three types:
    1. Sutures: the articular surfaces are connected by a thin layer of connective (sutural ligament). e.g. sutures of skull.
    2. Syndesmosis: Here two bones are linked together by interossei ligaments and membranes. e.g. interosseous radio-ulnar joint, interosseous tibiofibular joints, inferior tibiofibular joints.
    3. Gomphosis: These are specialized fibrous joints restricted to fixation of teeth in alveolar sockets of mandible and the maxillae. The root of the tooth is attached to the socket within the alveolus by periodontal ligament.
  2. Cartilaginous joint: Here bones forming the joint are united by hyaline or fibrocartilage.
  3. Synovial joint: These joints possess a cavity and the articular ends of bones forming the joint are enclosed in a fibrous capsule.

Reference: General Anatomy. Vishram Singh. 2nd edition. Chapter 7. p 89.

questions.text: Among the following nuclei, which of the following is medially located nuclei in cerebellum?
questions.solution:
Intracerebellar nuclei: They are masses of grey matter embedded in the white matter of the cerebellum. On each side of the midline they are four in number.

From lateral to medial side these are:

  1. Dentate nucleus: It is largest nuclei and receive afferent fibres from neocerebellum.
  2. Embolifirm nucleus: It is oval in shape and receive afferent fibres from paleocerebellum.
  3. Globose nucleus: It has similar connection to that of embolifirm nucleus.
  4. Fastigial nucleus: It lies near the midline in the vermis and close to the roof of the 4th ventricle. It receives afferent fibres from archicerebellum.

Putamen, lentiform and caudate nucleus are basal nuclei that are situated in the basal part of white core of each cerebral hemisphere lateral to thalamus.

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy. Vishram Singh. 4th edition. Chapter 10. p 119.

questions.text: Dural venous sinuses are found between the endosteal and meningeal layer of dura mater in the brain, identify the dural venous sinus arrow markers in the radiograph below.
questions.solution:
• The marked dural sinus in given radiograph is Straight sinus.
  • The dural venous sinuses are venous spaces, the walls of which are formed by dura mater. They have an inner lining of endothelium. There is no muscle in their wall. They have no valves.
  • Dural venous sinuses receives venous blood from the brain, the Meninges and bones of the skull.
  • There are 23 venous sinuses, of which 8 are paired and 7 are unpaired.
  • Straight sinus lies in the median plane within the junction of falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli.
  • Superior sagittal sinus occupies the upper convex, attached margin of the falx cerebri.
  • Inferior sagittal sinus lies in the posterior two third of lower concave free margin of the falx cerebri. It ends by joining the great cerebral vein to form straight sinus.
  • Confluence of sinuses is located at internal occipital protuberance and meeting point of superior sagittal, straight sinus, transverse sinus and occipital sinus.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 3. 9th edition, Chapter 12. p 217.

questions.text: The gland shown below is supplied through a parasympathetic system. It is supplied by which ganglion?
questions.solution:
• The gland shown in image is Lacrimal Gland.
  • Lacrimal gland is a serous gland situated chiefly in the lacrimal fossa on the anterolateral part of the roof of bony orbit and partly on the upper eyelid.
  • The lacrimal fluid secreted by the lacrimal gland flows into the conjuctival sac where it lubricates the front of the eye and deep surface of the lids.
  • The lacrimal gland is supplied by parasympathetic (secretomotor) fibres from Pterygopalatine ganglion.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 3. 9th edition, Chapter 2. p 80.

choices.text: Superior mesenteric vein & Inferior mesenteric vein

questions.text: A 40 yr old female presented with enlarged spleen and liver and also has presence of varices. A diagnosis of Portal vein hypertension was made. Portal vein is formed by union of which of the following veins?
questions.solution:
• Portal vein is a large vein which collects blood from:
    1. The abdominal part of the alimentary tract
    2. The gall bladder
    3. The pancreas
    4. The spleen
  • It convey blood to the liver. In the liver, the portal vein breaks up into sinusoids which are drained by the hepatic veins to the inferior vena cava.
  • The portal vein is about 8 cm long and is formed by the union of the superior mesenteric and splenic veins behind the neck of the pancreas at level of second lumbar vertebra.
  • Normal pressure in the portal vein is about 5-15 mm Hg. Portal hypertension (pressure above 40 mm Hg) can be caused by the following.
    1. Cirrhosis of Liver
    2. Banti's disease
    3. Thrombosis of portal vein
  • The effects of portal hypertension are as follows:
    1. Congestive splenomegaly
    2. Ascites
    3. Caput medusae, Oesphageal varices, Haemorrhoids

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 21. pp 330-333.

choices.text: Lateral margin is formed by Sartorius
Floor is formed by adductor longus

questions.text: All are true about the triangle shown in the image given below, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
• The triangle shown in image is femoral triangle.
  • Femoral triangle is a triangular depression on the front of the upper one-third of the thigh immediately below inguinal ligament.
  • Boundaries of femoral triangle are as follow:
    • laterally: by medial border of Sartorius
    • Medially: by medial border of adductor longus
    • Base: by inguinal ligament
  • Roof is formed by skin, superficial fascia and deep fascia
  • Floor is formed medially by adductor longus and pectineus and laterally by the psoas major and iliacus.

Contents:

  1. Femoral artery and its branches
  2. Femoral vein and its tributaries
  3. Femoral sheath enclose upper 4 cm of femoral vessels
  4. Nerves: Femoral nerve, nerve to pectineus, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve, lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 3. pp 52-53.

questions.text: A mother brings her child to your clinic with the following finding as shown in the image given below. What is the Nerve roots involved in this condition.
questions.solution:
• The child shown in the image has deformity of Erb's Paralysis.
  • Erb's point is the region of the upper trunk where 6 nerves meets. Injury to the upper trunk causes Erb's Paralysis.
  • Causes of injury: Undue separation of the head from the shoulder, which might occurs in the following: Birth injury/difficult childbirth, Fall on the shoulder, During anesthesia
  • Nerves root involved: Mainly C5 and the partly C6.
  • Muscles paralysed: Biceps brachii, Deltoid, Brachialis, and Brachioradialis. Partly Supraspinatus, infraspinatus and Supinator.
  • Deformity and position of the limb:
    • Arm: Hang by side; it is adducted and medially rotated.
    • Forearm: Extended and pronated.
  • The deformity is known as policeman's tip hand or waiter tip hand or porter's tip hand.

Disability: The following movements are lost:

  1. Abduction and lateral rotation of the arm at shoulder joint
  2. Flexion and supination of the forearm
  3. Biceps and Supinator jerks are lost.
  4. Sensations are lost over small area over the lower part of deltoid.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition. Chapter 4. p 64.

questions.text: A 30 YR old male met an accident and has injury in upper part of leg. He is unable to Dorsiflex the foot as well as unable to evert the foot. He is also complaining of decreased sensation over Dorsum of foot. Which Nerve is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
• The above patient has injury in upper part of leg that leads to involvement of Common peroneal nerve.
  • The common peroneal nerve is the smaller terminal branch of the sciatic nerve. It extends from superior angle of popliteal fossa to lateral angle of fossa and than winds around the posterolateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. It pierces the peroneus longus and divides into the superficial and the deep peroneal nerves.
    1. Superficial peroneal nerve: It supplies peroneus longus and peroneus brevis muscle. It supplies the lower one-third of lateral side of the leg and greater part of dorsum of foot. Peroneus longus and peroneus brevis are evertors of foot.
    2. Deep Peroneal nerve: It supplies the four muscles of anterior compartment of leg; tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus, extensor hallucis longus and peroneus tertius. It also supplies skin of adjacent side of the first and second toes. The muscles of anterior compartment are acts as dorsiflexor of foot.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 6. p 91.

questions.text: A 26 yr old male met an accident and X-ray findings are suggestive of Supracondylar Fracture at Humerus. When he attempts to make a fist, the index finger and middle finger are unable to flex completely. Which nerve is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
• Supracondylar fracture is common in young age. It is produced by a fall on the outstretched hand. The lower fragment is mostly displaced backwards, so that the elbow is unduly prominent. This fracture may cause injury to the median nerve.
  • The median nerve controls coarse movements of the hand, as it supplies most of long muscles of the front of forearm. It therefore called the labourer's nerve.
  • The median nerve supplies flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus (for middle and index finger). Patient is unable to flex the middle and index finger while making fist if median nerve is injured.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition. Chapter 9. p 143.

questions.text: All of the following structures develop from 2nd Pharyngeal Arch except?
questions.solution:
• The pharyngeal arches are five in number and present in lateral wall and floor of the primitive pharynx. They consists of a central core of mesoderm, lined externally by ectoderm and internally by endoderm.
  • Main derivatives of the pharyngeal arches:

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy. Vishram Singh. 3rd edition. Chapter 14. p 154.

questions.text: A 35 yr old male had an accident and X-ray findings are suggestive of Fracture of Medial Epicondyle. There is Hypothenar Muscle wasting and loss of sensation on little finger and medial half of ring finger. Which nerve is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
• The Patient had fracture of medial epicondyle. The ulnar nerve is injured in this case.
  • Ulnar nerve: It arises in the axilla from the medial cord of brachial plexus (C8, T1). It runs along medial side of brachial artery and lodges in a groove on back of medial epicondyle (Cubital tunnel).
  • It enter the forearm by passing between two heads of flexor carpi ulnaris and runs vertically downwards. it gives muscular branches to flexor carpi ulnaris and medial half of flexor digitorum profundus in forearm.
  • It enters the palm by passing superficial to flexor retinaculum in ulnar tunnel. It supplies Hypothenar muscles, 8 interossei and 3rd and 4th lumbricals muscles in hand. It supplies the skin of medial one-third of hand, little finger and medial one half of ring finger.

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy. Vishram Singh. Volume I. 4th edition. Chapter 13. p 180.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents in emergency after a road traffic accident with injury in arm. He Presents with inability to extend his wrist. On examination, there is loss of sensation of dorsum of lateral aspect of hand and fingers. Which is the most likely involved nerve?
questions.solution:
• The patient has injury in arm & he unable to extend wrist and sensory loss over dorsum of hand & fingers. The condition is wrist drop So most likely Radial nerve is involved.
  • Radial nerve: It is the largest branch of posterior cord of brachial plexus with root value of C5-C8 and T1. It supplies triceps muscle in arm region and supplies all extensor muscles at back of forearm.
  • Radial nerve is also supplies skin of back of arm (through posterior cutaneous nerve of arm), posterior surface of forearm (through posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm) and lateral 2/3 of dorsum of hand and lateral three and half fingers (superficial radial nerve).

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 1. 9th edition. Chapter 9. p 155.

questions.text: A 3 yr old boy has repeated episodes of sore throat and fever. He undergoes surgery to remove collections of Lymphoid Tissue Palatine Tonsils. The removed structures developed from which of the following Pharyngeal Pouches?
questions.solution:
• The patient undergone tonsillectomy due to repeated attack of tonsillitis.
  • The palatine tonsil is developed from second pharyngeal pouch.

Derivatives of Pharyngeal pouches are:

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology. Vishramsingh. 3rd edition. Chapter 14. P 157.

questions.text: The arrow marked area of skin of foot is supplied by which nerve?
questions.solution:
• The arrow marked area of skin of foot is cleft between first and second toes.
  • Deep peroneal nerve is terminal branch of common peroneal nerve and begins on lateral side of the neck of fibula. It ends on dorsum of foot by dividing into medial and lateral terminal branches.
    The medial terminal branch ends by supplying skin adjoining the first interdigital cleft.
  • Saphenous nerve, a branch from femoral nerve supplies the skin of medial side of leg and medial border of foot up to ball of great toe.
  • Sural nerve, a branch of tibial nerve supplies skin of the lower half of back of leg and of the lateral border of foot up to tip of little toe.
  • Superficial peroneal nerve supplies skin over entire dorsum of foot with exception as supply by above nerves.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 8. p 107.

questions.text: A patient presents with the symptoms (below the level of lesion) as shown in image. What is the most probable reason for this?
questions.solution:
• Above clinical symptoms suggestive of Brown sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord).
  • A patient shown in image has following symptoms:
    1. Ipsilateral loss of conscious proprioception and vibration: due to involvement of posterior columns.
    2. Ipsilateral spastic Hemiplegia: due to involvement of pyramidal tract.
    3. Contralateral loss of pain & temperature: due to involvement of spinothalamic tract.

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy. Vishram Singh. 4th edition. Chapter 7. p 73.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle do not take part in formation of marked structure?
questions.solution:
• The marked strucutre is perineal body.
  • It is a fibromuscular node situated in the median plane, about 1.25 cm in front of the anal margin and close to the bulb of the penis.
  • Ten muscles of perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.
    • 1. External anal sphincter.
    • 2. Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal.
    • 3 & 4. Bulbospongiosus (paired).
    • 5 & 6. Superficial transverse perinei (paired).
    • 7 & 8. Dep transverse perinei (paired).
    • 9 & 10. Levator ani (paired).
  • Ischiocavernosus: It is muscle of superficial perineal space. It covers the crus of penis or crus clitoridis. It arise from medial surface of ischial ramus and inserted by an aponeurosis into the sides and undersurface of anterior part of crus. It helps in maintaining erection of penis by compressing the crus.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Chapter 28. p 409.
